child.geography: Zimbabwe
child.pub-comments: nfluenced by Shona. About 70% of the vocabulary in Zimbabwe comes from Zulu, 24% from English, 6% from Afrikaans.

child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)
child.geography: Zambia
child.pub-comments: Influenced by Bemba. 70% of the vocabulary comes from Zulu, 24% from English, 6% from Afrikaans.

child.geography: South Africa, also spoken in Democratic Republic of the Congo, Namibia, Zambia, Zimbabwe.
child.alt-names: "Fanakalo", "Fanekolo", "Kitchen Kaffir", "Mine Kaffir", Piki, Isipiki, "Isikula", Lololo, Isilololo, Pidgin Bantu, Basic Zulu, Silunguboi
child.pub-comments: nfluenced by Shona in Zimbabwe. About 70% of the vocabulary in Zimbabwe comes from Zulu, 24% from English, 6% from Afrikaans. Influenced by Bemba in Zambia. 70% of the vocabulary comes from Zulu, 24% from English, 6% from Afrikaans.

child.geography: Zambia, may also be in Kenya.

child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)

child.geography: Nigeria, Sokoto State, Jega LGA, near the Dukawa.

child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)

child.geography: Liberia
child.pub-comments: As different from Standard English as is Sierra Leone Krio. Repidginized from American Black English of the 1800s (J. Holm).

child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)
Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)
child.geography: Tunisia; Dodecanese Islands west bank, Greece; Cyprus; other major Mediterranean ports.
child.pub-comments: Lexicon from Italian and Provençal. An earlier version may have been a pidginized Latin. On the Barbary Coast of North Africa in 1578, its lexicon came from Spanish and Portuguese. In Algeria in the 1830s, it drew increasingly from French, and later became the nonstandard French of that area. It may also have influenced other pidgins. There is a report of a present-day variety on the Aegean Islands, used as a pidgin in the southeastern Mediterranean region, to have mainly Arabic syntax, and vocabulary which is 65% to 70% Italian, 10% Spanish, and other Catalan, French, Ladino, and Turkish words. Documented in Djerba, Tunisia in 1353.

child.geography: Africa

child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)

child.geography: Nigeria, southern states and in Sabon Garis of the northern states, coastal and urban areas.
child.alt-names: Nigerian Creole English, Nigerian Pidgin English
child.pub-comments: The dialects listed may be very different from each other. Partially intelligible with Krio of Sierra Leone and Cameroon Pidgin. It is a creole with native speakers, as well as used as a pidgin between Africans and Europeans, and Africans from different languages.

child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)
Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)

child.geography: Sierra Leone, communities in Freetown, on the Peninsula, on the Banana Islands, York Island, in Bonthe, by de-tribalized Sierra Leoneans and as the lingua franca throughout the country. Also spoken in Gambia, Guinea, Senegal.
child.pub-comments: Krio and Jamaican Creole, and Krio and Sea Islands Creole may have some interintelligibility. There is linguistic influence from Yoruba (I. Hancock 1987).

child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)
child.geography: Equatorial Guinea, North central Bioko Island (Fernando Po), 6 communities in or near Malabo: Musola, Las Palmas, Sampaca, Basupu, Fiston, Balveri de Cristo Rey.
child.alt-names: Pidginglis, Fernandino, Fernando Po Krio, Criollo
child.pub-comments: Speakers came from Sierra Leone in 1827. Pidginglis may be a separate language from Krio.

child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)
child.geography: Cameroon, primarily in South West and North West provinces, and widespread elsewhere.
child.pub-comments: Similar to Krio of Sierra Leone and Pidgin English of various West African countries; probably an offshoot of 19th century Krio. Also similar to Sranan (Ian Hancock). There are dialect variations.

child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)
Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)
child.geography: Uganda, Bombo, 30 miles north of Kampala, Arua, and elsewhere in Uganda. Also spoken in Kenya.
child.pub-comments: Formerly a soldier language, which split off from Sudanese Pidgin Arabic about 1900.There are conflicting reports of intelligibility of Sudanese Creole Arabic. 90% of the lexicon comes from Arabic.

child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)
child.geography: Chad, West, Chari Baguirmi Prefecture, N'Djamena Subprefecture. North of Djermaya and between Karal and Tourba. Possibly also in the Bokoro Subprefecture around Ngoura. 23 villages.
child.pub-comments: A creole developed from Chadian Arabic (90% of the vocabulary) and Berakou (10%; Decobert). Babalia shares structural similarities with Juba Arabic. There is a post-creole continuum from Chadian Arabic to the Bagirmian basilect.

child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)
child.geography: Sudan, Southern Sudan, in the towns and many villages all over Equatoria Region, and up into Bahr al Ghazal and Upper Nile regions. Refugees have gone to other countries.
child.alt-names: Juba Arabic, Southern Sudan Arabic, Pidgin Arabic
child.pub-comments: Difficult intelligibility of Nubi, Sudanese Arabic, or Modern Standard Arabic.

child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)
Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)
child.geography: Kenya, also spoken in Tanzania.
child.pub-comments: May be adequately intelligible to speakers of standard Swahili. Cutchi-Swahili and Asian Swahili may not be the same.

child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)
Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)

Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)
child.geography: Senegal, Ziguinchor, Bignona, and Kolda. It overlaps from Guinea-Bissau and the Bijagos Islands.
child.pub-comments: The Senegal dialect is different from Guinea-Bissau, with some Pidgin French vocabulary. Intelligible with Guinea-Bissau Creole.

child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)

child.geography: Guinea-Bissau. Also Bijagos Islands. Also spoken in Gambia, Senegal, USA.
child.alt-names: Kiryol, Portuguese Creole, Kriulo, Guinea-Bissau Creole
child.pub-comments: The Senegal dialect is different from Guinea-Bissau, with some Pidgin French vocabulary. Intelligible with Guinea-Bissau Creole.

child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)
child.geography: São Tomé e Príncipe, on Príncipe Island.
child.pub-comments: The substratum was largely Kwa and Western Bantu languages; quite distinct from the creoles of Guinea-Bissau, Senegal, Gambia, and Cape Verde. Principense shares 77% lexical similarity with São Tomense, 67% with Angolar, 62% with Annobonese.

child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)
child.geography: São Tomé e Príncipe, all but the southern tip.
child.pub-comments: The substratum was largely Kwa and Western Bantu languages; quite distinct from the creoles of Guinea-Bissau, Senegal, Gambia, and Cape Verde. Lexical similarity 77% with Principense, 62% with Fa D'Ambu (Annobonese), 70% with Angolar.

child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)
Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)
child.geography: Santo Antão, São Vicente, São Nicolau, Sal, and Boa Vista

child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)
child.geography: Santiago, Maio, Fogo, and Brava islands

Cape Verde Islands, Sotavento dialect is on Santiago, Maio, Fogo, and Brava islands; Barlavento dialect is on Santo Antão, São Vicente, São Nicolau, Sal, and Boa Vista islands. Also spoken in France, Germany, Italy, Luxembourg, Netherlands, Portugal, Senegal, Spain, USA.

child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)
child.geography: Equitorial Guinea, Annobón Island, isolated from the mainland by 360 km of ocean (2,000), and in a community from Annobón living in Malabo on Bioko Island (500), a few on continental Equatorial Guinea. Also spoken in Spain.
child.pub-comments: Different from Fernando Po Krio and Crioulo of Guinea-Bissau and Kabuverdianu. Little variation between Annobonese in Annobón and Malabo. Lexical similarity 62.5% with São Tomense. 10% of the lexicon comes from Spanish. Also influenced by the Creole English of Bioko.

child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)
child.geography: São Tomé e Príncipe, on the southern tip. Most are around the town of São João dos Angolares, and some in the southern region of Caué.
child.pub-comments: The substratum was largely Kwa and Western Bantu languages; quite distinct from the creoles of Guinea-Bissau, Senegal, Gambia, and Cape Verde. The 33% of the Angolar lexicon not shared with São Tomense is largely of Bantu origin, apparently Kimbundu of Angola, with some from Kongo, Bini, and Ndingi. Lexical similarity 70% with São Tomense, 67% with Principense, 53% with Annobonese.

child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)

child.geography: Democratic Republic of the Congo, Bas-Congo and southern Bandundu provinces.
child.alt-names: Kikongo-Kutuba, Kikongo Simplifié, Kikongo Ya Leta, Kileta, Kikongo Commercial, Kibulamatadi
child.pub-comments: A creole based on the Kongo dialect spoken in Manianga area (Bas-Congo), but unintelligible to speakers of it or other Kongo dialects. Influenced by Lingala, French, restructured Swahili, Portuguese, and other local dialects. Kituba of Congo is closely related.

child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)
child.geography: Congo, spoken mainly between Brazzaville and Pointe-Noire.
child.pub-comments: Close to Kituba of Democratic Republic of the Congo.

child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)
Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)
Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)
child.geography: Rodrigues
child.pub-comments: Closer to French creoles of the Caribbean than to Réunion Creole (Philip Baker). Nearly identical to Rodrigues.

child.geography: Mauritius, also spoken in Madagascar.
child.alt-names: Mauritius Creole French, Kreole, Kreol, Mauritian, Maurysen

child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)
child.geography: Seychelles
child.alt-names: Seychellois Creole, Seychelles Creole French, Kreol, Creole, Ilois
child.pub-comments: Seychelles dialect is reported to be the same as Chagos. Structural differences with Mauritius are relatively minor. Not adequately intelligible with Réunion Creole.

child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)
child.geography: Réunion, also spoken in Comoros, Madagascar.
child.pub-comments: Two dialects: urban and popular; the former is closer to French, the latter more similar to Bantu and West African languages.

child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)
Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)
child.geography: Central African Republic. Scattered. Not in Cameroon. Also spoken in Chad, Congo, Democratic Republic of the Congo.
child.pub-comments: A rapidly spreading creole derived from Ngbandi. Lexical similarity 51% with French, 49% from African languages. However, the African-based words are used more frequently.

child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)
child.geography: Central African Republic, Mobaye Subprefecture, along the Ubangi River.
child.pub-comments: High intelligibility of Sango.

child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)
Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)
child.geography: South Africa, Transvaal.
child.pub-comments: It also includes some Bantu words.

child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)
child.geography: South Africa, in Gauteng province, around Johannesburg, Pretoria, Bloemfontein, and other cities.
child.pub-comments: Not intelligible to Afrikaans speakers. Uses many Afrikaans, English, and Bantu words, and others of unknown origin. Originated in the gold mines in Transvaal from 1886. Creolized by 1930.

child.geography: Africa

root.pub-comments: This is an amalgamation of subtrees of the pidgin and creole trees provided in Ethnologue. It has been broken into regions for ease of searching.
